description: From German Walzer, from walzen (“to dance”), from Old High German walzan (“to turn”), from Proto-Germanic *walt- (“to turn”), from Proto-Indo-European *wel- (“to turn”). Doublet of valse. More at *waltaną.

entries.meaning: A piece of music for this dance (or in triple time).

verbs.description: waltz (third-person singular simple present waltzes, present participle waltzing, simple past and past participle waltzed)

examples: They waltzed for twenty-one hours and seventeen minutes straight, setting a record.
While waltzing her around the room, he stepped on her toes only once.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive, usually with in, into, around, etc.) To move briskly and unhesitatingly, especially in an inappropriately casual manner, or when unannounced or uninvited.
examples: He waltzed into the room like he owned the place.
You can't just waltz him in here without documentation!

entries.meaning: (informal) To accomplish a task with little effort.
examples: Don't worry about the interview — you'll waltz it.
